t: The clouds do His bidding, traversing the whole earth, and the fire, sent from on high to consume mountains and forests, doth that which is commanded.
Verily, neither in beauty nor in power are these comparable unto Him.
Therefore, one cannot think nor say that these are gods, for they are powerless to render justice and to do good unto men.
Knowing then that these are no gods, fear them not!
For they can neither curse nor bless the kings,
Nor show signs in the heavens among the people; they shine not as the sun, nor give light as the moon.
The beasts are better than they, for they can flee to shelter and succor themselves.
In no wise is it manifest unto us that these are gods, therefore fear them not!
As a scarecrow in a field of cucumbers, that protecteth naught, so are their gods of wood, overlaid with gold and silver.
Yea, their gods of wood, overlaid with gold and silver, are like unto a thornbush in a garden, upon which all manner of birds alight, or like a dead man cast into the darkness.
By the purple and the linen that rot upon them, ye shall know that they are not gods. Finally, they shall be devoured and become a dishonor in the land.
Better is the righteous man, who hath no idols; he shall escape reproach!
The book of the words of Tobit, son of Tobiel, son of Ananiel, son of Aduel, son of Gabael, of the seed of Asael, of the tribe of Naphtali;
Who in the days of Shalmaneser king of the Assyrians was led captive out of Thisbe, which is at the right hand of that Galilee which is above Aser.
I Tobit have walked all the days of my life in the ways of truth and justice, and I did many almsdeeds to my brethren, and my nation, who came with me to Nineveh into the land of the Assyrians.

And when I was in mine own country, in the land of Israel, being but young, all the tribe of Naphtali my father fell from the house of David, and from Jerusalem, which was chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, that all tribes should sacrifice there: where the temple of the habitation of the most High was consecrated and built for all ages.
Now all the tribes which together revolted, and the house of my father Naphtali, sacrificed unto the heifer Baal.

But I alone went often to Jerusalem at the feasts, as it was ordained unto all the people of Israel by an everlasting decree, having the firstfruits and tenths of increase, and an offering of the sheep;

And gave them to the priests the sons of Aaron at the altar: also the tenth of all increase I gave to the sons of Levi, who ministered at Jerusalem: and the second tenth I sold away, and went, and spent it every year at Jerusalem:
And the third I gave unto them to whom it was meet, as Deborah my father's mother had commanded me, because I was left an orphan by my father.
Furthermore, when I was come to the age of a man, I took to wife of mine own kindred, and her name was Anna.
And when I had begotten a son, I called him Tobias.
And when we were carried away captives to Nineveh, all my brethren and those that were of my kindred did eat of the bread of the Gentiles.
But I kept myself from eating;
Because I remembered God with all my heart.
And the most High gave me grace and favour before Shalmaneser so that I was his purveyor.
And I went into Media, and bought for him till he died. Moreover I laid up bags of money with Gabael my brother of Gabrias at Rages a city of Media.
But when Shalmaneser was dead, Sennacherib his son reigned in his stead; whose estate was troubled, that I could not go into Media.
Now in the days of Shalmaneser I gave many alms to my brethren, and gave my bread to the hungry,
And my clothes to the naked: and if I saw any of my nation dead, or cast about the walls of Nineveh, I buried him.

And if the king Sennacherib had slain any, when he was come, and fled from Judea, I buried them privily. For in his wrath he killed many; but the bodies were not found, when they were sought for of the king.

And when one of the Ninevites went and complained of me to the king, that I buried them, and hid myself: then I fearing because I knew that the king was mindful of things, and that I was sought for to be put to death, I withdrew myself through fear.
Then all my goods were forcibly taken away, neither was there any thing left unto me, beside my wife Anna and my son Tobias.

But within forty days the king was slain by his own two sons, who fled into the mountains of Ararath; and Esarhaddon his son reigned in his stead; who appointed over all the accounts of his kingdom Achiacharus my brother Anael's son.

And Achiacharus intreated for me, and I returned to Nineveh. Now Achiacharus was cupbearer, and keeper of the signet, and steward, and overseer of the accounts: and Esarhaddon appointed him next unto him: and he was my brother Anael's son.

Therefore Tobit returned to his house, and Anna his wife, and Tobias his son; and they feasted. And after the feast was done, Tobit called his son Tobias, and said unto him, My son, go forth and see if thou canst find any that is poor of our brethren, who is mindful of God, and bring him unto me, that he may take part with me.
And when he had gone forth, he found a man of our kindred strangled, and cast in the street. And he said, Father, see, if I bury him not, I shall be put to death.
Then left he the dinner, and took him up, and carried him into an hidden place, and buried him.
After he had eaten his meat, he came again, and I said unto him, My son, who is he that is dead?
And he said, One of our brethren. And I said unto him, Tarry, my son, and eat no more till thou hast told me all.
Then he said unto me, He is strangled. Then I was sore afraid, and cast fear upon me, lest peradventure I should be punished for it: and I buried him, and hid myself.
And when I was come again to my house, and had washed me, I ate my meat in heaviness,
Remembering that prophecy of Amos, as he said, Your feasts shall be turned into mourning, and all your mirth into lamentation.
Therefore I went forth, and washed myself, and mourned, because I remembered the word of God.
And after I had made an end of mourning, I went and buried him. Then my neighbours mocked me,
And said, This fellow is not yet afraid to be put to death for this matter: who fled away; and yet, lo, he burieth the dead again.
The same night also I returned, and washed myself, and entered into my courtyard, and slept by the wall of the courtyard; and my face was uncovered,

And I knew not that there were sparrows in the wall: whose mute falling down into mine eyes caused whiteness: and I went to the physicians, but they helped me not: moreover Achiacharus did nourish me, until I went into Elymais.
Then my wife Anna did take women's works to do;
And when she had sent home to the owners their work, she received her wages, and brought also a kid.
And when it was come into mine house, I began to cry unto her, From whence is this kid? is it not stolen? render it to the owners; for it is not lawful to eat any thing that is stolen.
But she said, It was given me for a gift more than the wages. Howbeit I did not believe her, but bade her render it to the owners: and I was abashed at her.
Then she replied upon me, Where are now thine alms and thy righteous deeds? behold, thou and all thy works are known.
Then I being grieved did weep, and prayed with grief.
And said, O Lord, thou art just, and all thy works and all thy ways are mercy and truth, and thou judgest truly and justly for ever.
Remember me, and look on me, punish me not for my sins, and for my ignorances, and the sins of my fathers, who have sinned before thee:
For they obeyed not thy commandments: wherefore thou hast delivered us for a spoil, and unto captivity, and unto death, and for a proverb of reproach to all the nations among whom we are dispersed.

And now thy judgments are true: do with me according to thy will, and command my spirit to be taken from me, that I may depart, and become earth again: for it is better for me to die than to live, because I have heard false reproaches, and have much sorrow: command therefore that I may now be delivered from this distress, and go into the everlasting place: turn not thy face away from me.
It came to pass the same day, that Sara the daughter of Raguel in Ecbatana a city of Media, was also reproached by one of her father's maids;

Because that she had been married to seven husbands, whom Asmodeus the evil spirit had killed, before that they had lain with her. Dost thou not know, said she, that thou hast strangled thine husbands? thou hast had already seven husbands, neither wast thou worthy to have them.
Wherefore dost thou beat us? if they be dead, go thy ways after them, let us never see of thee either son or daughter.

When she heard these things, she was very sorrowful, so that she thought to have strangled herself; and she said, I am the only daughter of my father, neither hath he any child to be his heir, neither any near kinsman upon earth, to whom I may keep myself for a wife: wherefore do I tarry any longer here? and she wept.
And she said, I do beseech thee, O Lord, let me not hear these reproaches any more, but take me away from the earth.
Thou knowest, O Lord, that I never desired a husband, and that I have kept my body pure from all sin.
Never did I company with those that play: neither did I defile my self with the keepers of my flocks.
I never desired a man to touch me, nor have I given myself to any for impurity.
But I consent to die, rather than to hear these reproaches.
So the prayers of them both were heard before the most High.

And Raphael was sent to heal them both: to scale away the whiteness of Tobit's eyes, and to give Sara Raguel's daughter to Tobias to wife; and to bind Asmodeus the evil spirit; because she belonged to Tobias by right of inheritance. The selfsame time came Tobit home, and entered into his house, and Sara the daughter of Raguel came down from her upper chamber.
In that day Tobit remembered the money which he had committed to Gabael in Rages of Media,
And said with himself, I have asked for death; wherefore do I not call for my son Tobias, that I may signify to him of the money before I die?
And when he had called him, he said, My son, when I am dead, bury me, and despise not thy mother, but honour her all the days of thy life, and do that which shall please her, and grieve her not.
Remember, my son, that she saw many dangers for thee, when thou wast in her womb; and when she is dead, bury her beside me in the same grave.
My son, be mindful of the Lord our God all thy days, and let not thy will be set to sin, or to transgress his commandments: do uprightly all thy life long, and follow not the ways of unrighteousness.
For if thou deal truly, thy doings shall prosperously be directed to thee, and to all them that live justly.
Give alms of thy substance; and when thou givest alms, let not thine eye be envious, neither turn thy face from any poor, and the face of God shall not be turned away from thee.
If thou hast abundance give alms accordingly; if thou have but a little, be not afraid to give according to that little:
For thou layest up a good treasure for thyself against the day of necessity.
Because that alms do deliver from death, and suffereth not to come into darkness.
For alms is a good gift unto all that give it in the sight of the most High.

Beware of all whoredom, my son, and chiefly take a wife of the seed of thy fathers, and take not a strange woman to wife, which is not of thy father's tribe: for we are the children of the prophets, Noe, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: remember, my son, that our fathers from the beginning, even that they all took wives of their own kindred, and were blessed in their children, and their seed shall inherit the land.

Now therefore, my son, love thy brethren, and despise not in thy heart thy brethren, and the sons and daughters of thy people, in taking a wife of them: for in pride is destruction and much trouble, and in lewdness is decay and great want: for lewdness is the mother of famine.

Let not the wages of any man, which hath wrought for thee, tarry with thee, but give him it out of hand: for if thou serve God truly he will surely repay thee: be circumspect, my son, in all things thou doest, and be wise in all thy conversation.
Do that to no man which thou hatest: drink not wine to make thee drunken: neither let drunkenness go with thee in thy journey.
Give alms of thy substance; and when thou givest alms, let not thine eye be evil. Defraud not the poor of his living, and turn not away thy face from the needy.
Pour out thy bread on the burial of the just, but give nothing to the wicked.
Seek counsel of all that are wise, and despise not any counsel that is profitable.

Bless the Lord thy God alway, and desire of him that thy ways may be directed, and that all thy paths and counsels may prosper: for every nation hath not counsel; but the Lord himself giveth all good things, and he humbleth whom he will, as he will; now therefore, my son, remember my commandments, neither let them be put out of thy mind.
And now, my son, I inform thee that I have ten talents of silver deposited with Gabael, the son of Gabrias, at Rages of Media.
Fear not, my son, because we are become poor: thou hast much wealth, if thou fear God, and depart from all sin, and do that which is pleasing in his sight.
Then Tobias answered and said to his father Tobit, I will do all things which thou hast commanded me.

But how can I receive the money, seeing I know him not? Then he gave him the handwriting, and said unto him, Seek thee a man which may go with thee, whiles I yet live I will hire him: and prepare thou for the journey.

Then Tobit said, I have a note of his hand with me; so go and seek him out, and receive the money, and bring it here to me again. Behold, I have written down all the particulars about the sum, even unto two parts.
So he went forth to seek a man to travel with him into Media; and found an angel who stood before him, but he knew not that he was an angel of God.
And he said unto him, Whence art thou, brother? And he said, I am of the sons of Israel. And Tobias said unto him, Knowest thou the way that leadeth to Media?
And he said, I know it well: and I have lodged many times with Gabael, who is our brother, dwelling at Rages in Media. And Tobias said, Tarry for me, I pray thee, until I tell my father.
Then Tobias said unto him, Tarry here, brother, for I go into my father's house, for I must ask him.
So he tarried, and Tobias went and told his father, and said unto him, I have found one which is of our brethren, even of the sons of Israel.

And he said unto him, Call him unto me, that I may know of what tribe he is, and whether he be a trusty man to go with thee. So Tobias went and called him, and said, Young man, my father calleth for thee.

So he went in, and Tobit saluted him, and said unto him, Brother, of what tribe art thou? And he said unto him, Of the sons of Naphtali, who are carried away captive to Nineveh. Then Tobit said unto him, Knowest thou Gabael our brother, who dwelleth at Rages in Media? And he said, I know him well, and have lodged in his house.
And Tobit said unto him, Art thou trusty, and wilt thou go with my son Tobias unto Rages?
And he said, I will go with him, and I know the way well: for I have lodged with Gabael.
Then Tobit said unto him, Tarry here, I pray thee, until I send for one to write an agreement between us, and I will reward thee according to thy service.

And the angel said unto him, I will tarry. So Tobit went out, and called a scribe, and said unto him, Write an agreement between me and this young man, that he may go with my son Tobias unto Rages of Media.
